g.text: Martínez-Casado et al. Defects and Adsorption on Anatase

when the donated electrons are accommodated in the described
positions, a four–trilayer slab provides an adequate description.
The localized states associated with the Ti
rigorous test of the ﬂexibility of the local Gaussian basis sets used.
The nature of the localized d-state is very diﬀerent to that of the
delocalized d-band of the undoped system. We therefore expect
some sensitivity to the ﬂexibility of the basis set used to describe
the DOS in the band gap
is displayed for both the oxygen subsurface vacancy with the
two basis sets, BS2 and BS3. Although the calculations using BS2
reproduce the surface structure very accurately, the computed
position of the defects state relative to the CBM diﬀers by 6% to
that predicted by the more ﬂexible BS3. The computational time
increases by 33%by using BS3 instead of BS2.
an increase of the surface band gap of around 2% when an
oxygen monovacancy is present. This result can be due again to
the approximation of considering few layers to simulate the real
surface or to the interaction of polaronic distortions as explained
above. AE–LCAO(HSE) also describes very similar peaks for the
gap state corresponding to the Ti
ion on the outermost layer in
both defects, as it can be seen in
Band gap for the stoichiometric anatase (101) and the defective
surface by using AE–LCAO and PP–PW.
The heterogeneous photocatalysis is based on the ability of
photocatalysts to absorb the light energy required to generate
electron–hole pairs for a surface reaction. TiO
ultraviolet (UV) light, but its optical properties can be enhanced
by defect engineering. Both oxygen vacancies and hydrogen
adsorption give rise to local states below the CB edge, which can
extend the light absorption of TiO
from the UV to the visible
ranges. The formation energy is calculated by using the formula:
are the energies of the defective and non
the oxygen molecule. The calculated formation energy with AE–
LCAO (HSE) is 2.6 eV, in good agreement with the value 2.9 eV,
The adsorption mechanism for H investigated here
corresponds to the R arrangement in the DFT study by
, since this was found to be the most
favorable adsorption mode. A hydrogen atom is adsorbed
onto a surface oxygen atom, upon which a reduction of
a nearby titanium atom takes place. In our calculation,
a neutral H atom is adsorbed to O
and the donation of an electron to the
This electron is transferred to the oxide lattice, and occupies
orbitals of the nearest neighbor Ti
ions. As a result, this Ti
ion. The analysis of the spin (unpaired electrons)
population conﬁrms the transfer of an electron onto the
Ti ion. The magnetic moment is 0.920
